I have a general question/concern for the netty connector.  How or will this work for multiple instances of this connector?  I see that the port is statically set.  So I am assuming that this connector can only have a parallelism of 1?

Perhaps @erenavsarogullari can chime in?

This may be related to the matching order of routing and MATCH_ALL.
https://github.com/AmateurEvents/pulsar/commit/7f0eca524581ae9bb76c6a7d1b50b68506895542
https://github.com/AmateurEvents/pulsar/commit/fcf9e36c6f09c84800578e9e5fef7b06f1619b0d
After I set up the code like this, curl http://localhost:8080/metrics could return metrics info.
It’s not ideal, though the HTTP response is 302 redirect to /metrics so any http client following redirects is working
run java8 tests

@jerrypeng - you can check the conversation that I had with @erenavsarogullari - https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3179#discussion_r241618154  

this connector can only be used in containerized environment. it can't be used in thread and process runtime. it is already documented - http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/io-tcp/#source
@sijie  i see

@sijie @jerrypeng I don’t think it’s necessarily limited to 1 single instance. If you open the socket with “reuse port” flag, the OS will let multiple processes to listen on same port. A new connection will then be bound to just one among these processes

@merlimat "reuse port" doesn't help. it is actually making things worse. for example, if two users submitting 2 connectors with same binding port, that will be very confusing. so we shouldn't recommend people to use this connector in a non-container runtime.

And with the python urllib2 package, we can get result through http://localhost:8080/metrics
```python
import urllib2

url = "http://localhost:8080/metrics"
res = urllib2.urlopen(url)
print res.read()
```

Hi All, thanks for the highlight and discussion.

Yep, @sijie has highlighted at previous review. Container/Pod level port isolation can help to be created for multiple connector instance.

As an alternative approach, i was thinking about finding and setting available tcp/udp port under hood in the light of the `parallelism` level. In this case, tcp/udp client(user) needs to know used port(s) to connect to server/connector(s). Maybe not an ideal solution but used port(s) can be logged for notification.

@vincent-pli : currently it is not supported yet. One solution is to use pulsar functions. You can write a pulsar function to filter the messages by user_id and route the messages to user's own topic.

@JevonQ 

If you have a DNS for your brokers, your pulsar service url would be:

- web service url : http://<dns>:8080/
- broker service url: pulsar://<dns>:8080/

@sijie Thanks for your reply, but I'm still not clear. 

For the multi-clusters environment like I given in my previous question, suppose I have a domain name named pulsar.east-china.com which is provided for pulsar client to use, so how should I set the A record in DNS server for pulsar.east-china.com? I don't think it can work if I config DNS as follows:
pulsar.east-china.com    IN  A  B1-ip-address
pulsar.east-china.com    IN  A  B2-ip-address
pulsar.east-china.com    IN  A  B3-ip-address

That's because none of brokers has the instance-wide metadata. Let's think of this case, if a pulsar client is created with pulsar.east-china.com and the DNS server return B2-ip-address to the client, then it will make a connection with B2. If the client continue to create a Consumer on T3 which is owned by B3, B2 will not find the topic and return an error?

For a single cluster environment, if I use the built-in discovery service, what address should I use for web-service-url and broker-service-url while executing initialize-cluster-metadata?

oh sorry, I misunderstood your question.

* for multiple cluster case:

> Suppose I have a pulsar instance which consists of 3 pulsar clusters(C1, C2, C3), each cluster has one broker(B1, B2, B3), each broker manages one topic (T1, T2, T3). 

I am not sure what do you want to achieve here. can you describe a bit more on your use case?
Are you going to create a *global* cluster of C1, C2, C3? or do you want to ensure data is replicated across multiple clusters?

* for simple cluster environment

technically, the web-service-url and broker-service-url in a single cluster is not really used. those service urls are needed when you have more clusters and want to do geo-replication between clusters. You need to tell what are the service urls for each cluster. So in that sense, people are using DNS of the brokers for the web-service-url and broker-service-url.

@sijie , for this issue, what I am considering is using zk temporary node when update any partitions for topic, and if creating succeeded , the watch on this temporary node will tell all producer/consumer reconnect this topic , the current producer/consumer will get from api, what do you think about this ?

@merlimat If I am not wrong, your point is in the future , client would subscribe the system topics to get the these updates, and each type of update could have its own topic ? and the client could be producer, consumer, and any admin tools.  and only brokers would connect to zk only and get some changes and push to the "system" topics ?
Correct, that will be a general solution for a variety of problems

The situation is that:  `create-partitioned-topic` is an operation to create zookeeper data for topic. while get `partitioned-stats` try to get service stats for these [sub-partitioned-topics](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/admin/impl/PersistentTopicsBase.java#L1281) in broker. 
Since no producer and subscription has ever been created, so sub-partitioned-topics is not served by any broker, and [pulsar().getAdminClient().topics()](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/admin/impl/PersistentTopicsBase.java#L639), will return `Status.NOT_FOUND`, and report "Internal topics have not been generated yet".
Maybe we could turn the report messages to some thing like: "Internal topics have not been served by broker for no producer/consumer created yet"
retest this please

> Yes, I want to create a multi-cluster instance without replication among themselves and allow users to access the topic within each cluster. I cannot figure out a way to achieve this.

if it is "multi-cluster" instance without replication, then each cluster is a separate cluster. You have to manage which topic in which cluster.

Alternatively, you can setup a "global" instance, which requires a "global" zookeeper that spreads across multiple physical locations. In this way, pulsar will be acting as a "whole" system and managing the topic assignments. 

> does that mean I need to set the url address to the node ip where the pulsar discovery process run? 

If you want to setup additional discovery service, then the service urls are the DNS of the discovery service nodes and you have to run several processes for fault tolerance.

However you don't have to do so, broker already offers discovery. If you have DNS or load balancer for your brokers, you can just use that DNS in the service urls.
run java8 tests

@liketic the pr looks good generally. however I would suggest splitting the changes into two separate PRs. the first PR focuses on documentation and website, making sure all the docs are using configuration store instead of global zookeeper; the second RP is removing the deprecated options or flags.

> I want to know if creating/delete topic in run time is expensive or not.

Creating and deleting topics should be relatively cheap. However one thing to be kept in mind is that the number of topics that a single Pulsar cluster can support is bounded by how much metadata your zookeeper cluster can store for Pulsar. If you are going down into this approach, you might need to do a capacity plan to figure out how many of per-user-id topics you need.
Got it, many thanks
@cckellogg please take a look as well

I have been doing a lot of Kotlin programming recently. One of the advantages of Kotlin is that it still supports JDK 1.6 because Kotlin is a very popular language for developing Android apps and the support for JDK 1.6 is a must. One approach to provide a pre-JDK1.8 client library is to rewrite or create an additional client library which is written in pure Kotlin. With proper annotations added, the Kotlin version of the client library can also be accessed by Java code without the need to program in Kotlin. This change also addresses the need for supporting Android as client.

@merlimat is right.  
```shell
$curl -v -L http://localhost:8080/metrics 
$wget -q -O - http://localhost:8080/metrics
```
these shell command could return metrics info.

To create a Kotlin client library, we do not need to do it completely from scratch. Jetbrains' Intellij provides a tool to convert Java code to Kotlin. Although the conversion is not perfect and still requires additional manual fixes and porting work, it can be a very good initial version for making a workable Kotlin client library.

Writing a client is probably easy. As what you said, there are tools on doing the initial work. However I think the main concern is maintainability (e.g. is the client production battle tested, are there people dedicated on maintaining it, fixing bugs and etc). What we have done in pulsar is trying to maintain two battle tested versions of clients, one is java and the other is c++. All other non-java clients are just simple wrappers of C++ client. This approach is kind of working well and ensure having high quality pulsar clients of different languages. Although I am not familiar with kotlin, I can’t speak what would be the best approach for kotlin.

cp: target '/pulsar/generated-site/content' is not a directory

should be easy enough to fix?

>  Does that mean the pulsar client can find which broker hosts the topic via any broker?

yes.

all the brokers registered under same zookeeper instance will learn how topics are assigned to the broker. so when pulsar client connects to any broker, it will discover the right owner broker of the topic and then establish the connection with owner broker.

>  is it the official versioned zookeeper or a modified versioned zookeeper?

yes you can use your own zookeeper.

@HaraldGustafsson you made the request directly to the REST api, and not through the admin api?

@ivankelly yes, I'm using the REST API directly from a Python client.

Here is the method that delete the namespace:

    async def namespace_remove(self, tenant, namespace):
        retry = 20
        while retry > 0:
            try:
                # Get topics
                ns_path = "{prefix}/persistent/{tenant}/{namespace}".format(
                    prefix=self.path_prefix,
                    namespace=namespace,
                    tenant=tenant)
                async with self.session1.get(ns_path, **self._extra_args()) as resp:
                    try:
                        topics = await resp.json()
                        topics = [t.split("/", 4)[-1] for t in topics]
                    except:
                        topics = []
                        text = await resp.text()
                        _log.exception("Failed getting topic list when deleting namespace {} {}".format(resp.status, text))
                    _log.debug("pulsar broker namespace topics status {} {}".format(resp.status, topics))
                # Remove topics
                if topics:
                    await self.topic_remove(tenant, namespace, topics)
                #Delete namespace
                ns_path = "{prefix}/namespaces/{tenant}/{namespace}".format(
                    prefix=self.path_prefix,
                    namespace=namespace,
                    tenant=tenant)
                _log.debug("pulsar broker namespace remove {}".format(ns_path))
                async with self.session1.delete(ns_path, **self._extra_args()) as resp:
                    _log.debug("pulsar broker namespace delete status {} {}".format(resp.status, await resp.text()))
                    status = resp.status
                return status
            except OSError as error:
                if error.errno == 24:
                    # Too many files open, retry
                    retry -= 1
                    await asyncio.sleep(0.5)
                    continue
                _log.exception("Failed namespace_remove")
                return hs.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR
            except Exception as error:
                _log.exception("Failed namespace_remove")
                return hs.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR

The `self.session1` has a session pool of size 1 so only one simultaneous Admin API call.

we create-partitioned-topic  is an operation to create zookeeper data for topic, If no results are created，return "Internal topics have not been generated yet".  If zookeeper data has been created, but no producer and subscription has ever been created, partitioned-stats should return topic default info, like:
```shell
$ ./code/pulsar/pulsar_ms/bin/pulsar-admin topics create-partitioned-topic persistent://public/default/test-1 -p 2
$ ./code/pulsar/pulsar_ms/bin/pulsar-admin topics partitioned-stats  persistent://public/default/test-1
{
  "msgRateIn" : 0.0,
  "msgThroughputIn" : 0.0,
  "msgRateOut" : 0.0,
  "msgThroughputOut" : 0.0,
  "averageMsgSize" : 0.0,
  "storageSize" : 0,
  "publishers" : [ ],
  "subscriptions" : { },
  "replication" : { },
  "metadata" : {
    "partitions" : 2
  },
  "partitions" : { }
}
```
when producer and subscription has ever been created, return like:
```shell
$ ./code/pulsar/pulsar_ms/bin/pulsar-client consume -s "test_1_sub" persistent://public/default/test-1
$ ./code/pulsar/pulsar_ms/bin/pulsar-admin topics partitioned-stats  persistent://public/default/test-1
{
  "msgRateIn" : 0.0,
  "msgThroughputIn" : 0.0,
  "msgRateOut" : 0.0,
  "msgThroughputOut" : 0.0,
  "averageMsgSize" : 0.0,
  "storageSize" : 0,
  "publishers" : [ ],
  "subscriptions" : {
    "test_1_sub" : {
      "msgRateOut" : 0.0,
      "msgThroughputOut" : 0.0,
      "msgRateRedeliver" : 0.0,
      "msgBacklog" : 0,
      "blockedSubscriptionOnUnackedMsgs" : false,
      "unackedMessages" : 0,
      "msgRateExpired" : 0.0,
      "consumers" : [ ]
    }
  },
  "replication" : { },
  "metadata" : {
    "partitions" : 2
  },
  "partitions" : { }
}
```

@HaraldGustafsson 
So, it turns out this isn't a bug but just something quite user unfriendly to configure.

To delete a namespace, all bundles of the namespace also need to be deleted. The broker does do this automatically, though the bundles may be owned by different brokers, so as part of the rest operation, the broker has to call out to other brokers (even if there are none, it calls out to itself).

It uses the admin client, which internally calls the rest api to do this. If authorization is enabled, then this admin client must be configured to authenticate itself with a role which can perform the operation.

See https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3340/files, where "brokerClient" parameters are configured.

For TLS, I don't think there's any way around requiring that the brokerClient be configured with a cert for a superuser, since the we can't forward credentials. 

It should be possible to do something nicer though. With JWT we can just forward the token. Or we could simply allow client local to the broker to have full super user privs, (since they have access to ZK, they do anyhow). Something like an auth plugin which writes a something to zk to auth, and the broker auth provider checks this to authorize the client as the role they are requesting. @jai1 @merlimat WDYT?

In any case, I'll close this issue, as its a configuration issue. I've pushed a test to verify the functionality.

```
 Sets the timeout in milliseconds for unacknowledged messages. The
          timeout needs to be greater than 10 seconds. An exception is thrown if
          the given value is less than 10 seconds. If a successful
          acknowledgement is not sent within the timeout, all the unacknowledged
          messages are redelivered.
```
I was setting the value 5000ms which is less than 10000
as discussed with @codelipenghui , above code is reproduce-able under both 2.2.0 and 2.2.1, and seems related with batch.
